stem: Which intervention is MOST appropriate for a postpartum patient experiencing heavy vaginal bleeding and dizziness, with vital signs showing hypotension and tachycardia?

rationale.correct: Initiate fundal massage to promote uterine contraction and reduce bleeding. Fundal massage is the first-line intervention for postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony. A boggy uterus is a primary indicator of uterine atony.

mnemonic.meaning: Consider the TONE (uterine atony), Trauma, Tissue (retained placenta), and Thrombin (coagulation disorders) when assessing postpartum hemorrhage.

rationale.incorrect: Elevating the legs can improve venous return and blood pressure, but it does not address the source of the bleeding and is not the priority.

questionTrap.explanation: The distractors focus on supportive measures for hypovolemia or monitoring, but the MOST appropriate initial action addresses the root cause: uterine atony.

clinicalPearls: Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as >500 mL blood loss after vaginal delivery or >1000 mL blood loss after cesarean delivery.
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.
Fundal massage is a critical first-line intervention for uterine atony.
Other interventions for postpartum hemorrhage may include medications (e.g., oxytocin, misoprostol), bimanual compression, and ultimately, surgical intervention if conservative measures fail.

itemContext.sbar:
**S:** 28-year-old female, G2P2, Postpartum Day 1, experiencing heavy vaginal bleeding and dizziness. Uncomplicated vaginal delivery occurred yesterday. No known bleeding disorders. 
**B:** Patient had an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Estimated blood loss (EBL) during delivery was within normal limits. 
**A:** Patient reports feeling lightheaded and weak. Assessment reveals a boggy uterus and continuous, heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Vital signs show hypotension (90/60 mmHg) and tachycardia (110 bpm). Hemoglobin and hematocrit levels are trending downward. 
**R:** Recommend immediate fundal massage, assessment of vital signs every 5 minutes, and notification of the healthcare provider for potential pharmacological interventions and further evaluation.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
• General: Appears pale and diaphoretic.
  • Cardiovascular: Tachycardia present.
  • Abdomen: Fundus boggy and difficult to locate.
  • Genitourinary: Heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Saturated perineal pad.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• Monitor vital signs every 5 minutes.
  • Initiate fundal massage.
  • Assess vaginal bleeding.
  • Notify healthcare provider.
